Topic.Title: Only green On My Screen

Message.Msg: I tossed some shares at Wednesdays peak and bought them back about .20 cheaper Thursday, so that was good, but my "oh #$%$ what if we don't hold 12" hedge got tossed to the dogs at a loss of about .15 each, so the day ended up a wash aside from gains on the repurchased shares and my leaps. Those are what put me over the line to end the day with about a .45% overall gain, otherwise I'd have been in the red with everyone else. That was an absolutely brutal day and I hope we don't see one like it for a VERY long time.

Topic.Title: I'll Praise Ya While I Kiil Ya!....

Message.Msg: I know this is hard to believe but those that habitually carry often for that they have a weapon on them or in their luggage. My wheelchair went to the VA once for repairs and I forgot to remove the concealed weapon. Fortunately it was well enough concealed that they partially disassembled the chair, put it back together, and tested it, yet never found the loaded Glock 34 (with one spare 17rd mag and one spare 32rd mag) in its compartment. An Airline, they would have found it most likely. And technically a power wheelchair, though its checked luggage, goes through the security checkpoint (which would have missed it) and then is inspected and loaded on the plane (which would have found it), is treated more like carryon for security purposes.

Message.Title: gop just can't seem to overcome its racism and misogyny
Message.Msg: (of course some would say that is why they are attracted to the gop and pre 20th century ideas) SPRINGFIELD, Ill. (AP) — An Illinois Republican official resigned from his leadership post Thursday amid outrage over an email in which he berated a biracial former Miss America as a "street walker" who could fill a law firm's "minority quota" if she loses her bid for Congress. The controversy, involving a county GOP leader in central Illinois who campaigned for U.S. Rep. Rodney Davis, created a new rift for Republicans already struggling to expand and attract women and minority voters. Davis demanded the resignation of the county official, Jim Allen, after learning of what he called a "wrong, appalling and incredibly demeaning" email targeting Erika Harold, Davis' opponent in the March 2014 Republican primary. Sent to Republican blogger Doug Ibendahl, the email referred to Harold as a "street walker" and "love child" of Democrats and suggested the Harvard graduate could fill a "minority quota" at a law firm should she lose the race.

Message.Title: Interesting NSA surveillance twist
Message.Msg: It was bound to happen.... funny though! ==================== Lawyers eye NSA data as treasure trove for evidence in murder, divorce cases ----------------------------------- By Bob Sullivan, Columnist, NBC News The National Security Agency has spent years demanding that companies turn over their data. Now, the spy agency finds the shoe is on the other foot. A defendant in a Florida murder trial says telephone records collected by the NSA as part of its surveillance programs hold evidence that would help prove his innocence, and his lawyer has demanded that prosecutors produce those records. On Wednesday, the federal government filed a motion saying it would refuse, citing national security. But experts say the novel legal argument could encourage other lawyers to fight for access to the newly disclosed NSA surveillance database. "What's good for the goose is good for the gander, I guess," said George Washington University privacy law expert Dan Solove. "In a way, it's kind of ironic."

Message.Title: Private sector embarrassed again
Message.Msg: Three States Dump Major Private Prison Company In One Month State lawmakers who embraced private prisons as a cost-cutting measure are starting to have trouble ignoring their abysmal conditions. Corrections Corporation of America, the largest and most powerful private prison company in the nation, lost four prison contracts in the past month after extensive reports of abuse, neglect, and even fraud within their operations. Idaho cut ties with the corporation on Wednesday, which turned the state’s largest prison into a violent hellhole inmates called “Gladiator School.” Earlier this year, CCA was caught understaffing the prison and using prison gangs to control the population. The company admitted to falsifying nearly 4,800 hours of staffing records to squeeze more money out of the state for nonexistent security work. Shift logs at the prison showed the same security guards working for 2 to 3 days at a time without breaks. Last week, Texas closed two CCA prisons, including one with a history of suspicious prisoner deaths. One lawsuit alleges prison staff ignored an inmate’s cries for medical assistance, forcing her to give birth in a prison toilet to a baby that died four days later. CCA was also booted from Mississippi earlier this month after multiple deadly riots over poor food and sanitation, lack of medical care, and mistreatment by guards. Mississippi is hiring another private prison company, MTC, to take over CCA’s contract — even though MTC runs another prison with the highest inmate assault rate in the state. Mississippi already terminated contracts with the other major private prison company, GEO Group, after it was found guilty of turning a juvenile facility into “a cesspool of unconstitutional and inhuman acts.” Despite this record, the state is apparently not ready to give up on private prisons.

Topic.Title: Private sector embarrassed again

Message.Msg: Prisons, justice, and corrections should NEVER be privatized as the profit motive is enough to make companies treat the inmates as cattle to be harvested at need from among the free population in order to keep their occupation numbers high and their profits up. The corporatization of the Justice system is among the most egregious of changes in our country over the last 20 years. Texas has started to take steps to address the worst violators, but there will always be some in the gray areas as long as privately run prisons continue to exist at all.

Topic.Title: ETFC is still looking for new normal

Message.Msg: Since its seems we have broken out are you expecting a continuation move into earnings? Regardless what are you expecting after they report?

Topic.Title: ETFC is still looking for new normal

Message.Msg: At this point I have no idea what it's going to do. IF the accumulation is institutional then I expect them to keep buying into earnings at least until they've gradually accumulated their desired position. If this is primarily retail driven then I have NO idea what could happen. Retail investors have a habit of trading with their emotions rather than with logic, and my inability to anticipate their reactions is one of the primary causes of most of the losses I incur trading. That's one reason I started staying with companies that I could hold and trade long term, but I haven't gotten the knack of predicting short term movements even now, and so I continue. For those that DO have that knack, well, if they also have the knack of finding hidden value (my speciality) then they're gonna get stinking rich.

Topic.Title: I guess with the June $12 options expiring today we are stuck here.

Message.Msg: We did very well considering max pain combined with a price already hovering near it. I'm happy to see us break and sustain $12+ going into earnings. Further the rather gradual rise in the price is also encouraging as its shown little signs of weakness on testing. Decent volumes, potentially higher interest rates, declining default rates, increasing real estate prices for the properties they've had to foreclose on. What''s not to like?
